message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: import java.io.*;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
        String line;
        while ((line = br.readLine()) != null) {
            StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(line);
            int i = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
            int j = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
            int from = Math.min(i, j);
            int to = Math.max(i, j);
            int max = 0;
            for (int k = from; k <= to; k++) {
                int cycles = cycleLength(k);
                if (cycles > max) {
                    max = cycles;
                }
            }
            System.out.println(i + " " + j + " " + max);
        }
    }

    private static int cycleLength(int n) {
        int length = 1;
        while (n != 1) {
            if (n % 2 == 0) {
                n /= 2;
            } else {
                n = 3 * n + 1;
            }
            length++;
        }
        return length;
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: The code reads the input using BufferedReader and StringTokenizer. It tokenizes the input line into two integers i and j. It then calculates the cycle length for all numbers between i and j (inclusive) and keeps track of the maximum cycle length. The cycle length of a number is the number of steps it takes to reach 1 when applying the 3n+1 problem rules. The cycle length for each number is calculated in the cycleLength method. The result is then printed out.
